{{Infobox film | name = Baiveriyaa | image = Baiveriyaa.jpg | caption = Official film poster | director = [[Yoosuf Shafeeu]] | producer = [[Niuma Mohamed]]
Ismail Shafeeq | screenplay = [[Yoosuf Shafeeu]] | writer = | starring = [[Yoosuf Shafeeu]]
[[Sheela Najeeb]]
[[Ahmed Azmeel]]
[[Maleeha Waheed]]
[[Ahmed Saeed (actor)|Ahmed Saeed]] | cinematography = | editing = [[Yoosuf Shafeeu]] | music = | studio = Envision Entertainment | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2016|12|14}} | runtime = | country = Maldives | language = Dhivehi }} '''''Baiveriyaa''''' is a 2016 Maldivian [[comedy film]] written and directed and edited by [[Yoosuf Shafeeu]]. Produced by [[Niuma Mohamed]] and Ismail Shafeeq under Envision Entertainment, the film stars [[Yoosuf Shafeeu]], [[Sheela Najeeb]], [[Ahmed Azmeel]], [[Maleeha Waheed]] and [[Ahmed Saeed (actor)|Ahmed Saeed]] in pivotal roles. The film was released on 14 December 2016. The film revolves around an aspiring actress who flees from her family to pursue a career in the film industry and the suspicions and confusions that arise.{{cite news|url=https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/10286 |title=Last film of the year, "Baiveriyaa" releasing today |language=Dhivehi |work=Mihaaru |last=Adhushan |first=Ahmed |date=14 December 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330145254/https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/10286 |deadurl=no |archivedate=30 March 2018 |accessdate=30 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} == Cast == * [[Yoosuf Shafeeu]] as Werash * [[Sheela Najeeb]] as Riyasha * [[Ahmed Azmeel]] as Yanish * [[Maleeha Waheed]] as Iwrisha * [[Ahmed Saeed (actor)|Ahmed Saeed]] as Janu * [[Nashidha Mohamed]] as Noora * Ahmed Sunie as Wafir * Mohamed Faisal as Bassam * Hussain Shibau as Nasir * Ahmed Rifau * Maisha Ahmed * [[Fathimath Azifa]] ==Release== Producer Ismail Shafeeq conceptualised the film in 2013 and shared it with Yoosuf Shafeeu who wrote the screenplay, then directed, starred in, and edited the film. The film was announced on 6 June 2016.{{cite news|url=https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/1025 |title="Baiveriyaa": A comedy coming to screen this year |language=Dhivehi |work=Mihaaru |last=Adhushan |first=Ahmed |date=6 June 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330142538/https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/1025 |deadurl=no |archivedate=30 March 2018 |accessdate=30 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} The film was released on 14 December 2016.{{cite news|url=https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/11095 |title=Two shows of "Baiveriya" screening at olympus this week |language=Dhivehi |work=Mihaaru |last=Adhushan |first=Ahmed |date=3 January 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330143550/https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/11095 |deadurl=no |archivedate=30 March 2018 |accessdate=30 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} Upon release the film was positively received by critics. Nazim Hassan of ''Avas'' applauded the comical timing of the characters and picked the arguments between Shafeeu and Najeeb as the highlight of the film. Hassan was dissatisfied with the length of the film though he praised the "twist at the end" of the film.{{cite news|url=https://avas.mv/26970 |title=Baiveriyaa: A fun and entertaining film |language=Dhivehi |work=Avas |last=Hassan |first=Nazim |date=17 December 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330145015/https://avas.mv/26970 |deadurl=no |archivedate=30 March 2018 |accessdate=30 March 2018 |df=dmy-all}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:2016 films]] [[Category:Maldivian films]] {{Maldives-film-stub}}

{{Infobox national football team | Name = Burkina Faso | Badge = Burkinabe FF (logo).png | Nickname = | Association = [[Fédération Burkinabé de Foot-Ball]] | Sub-confederation = [[West African Football Union|WAFU]] (West Africa) | Confederation = [[Confederation of African Football|CAF]] | Coach = | Most caps = | Top scorer = | FIFA Trigramme = BFA | Home Stadium = [[Stade du 4-Août]] | FIFA Rank = {{FIFA Women's World Rankings|BFA}} | FIFA max = 92 | FIFA max date = December 2009 | FIFA min = 148 | FIFA min date = September 2015 | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=FFFFFF|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=FFFFFF | pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=40C040|body2=40C040|rightarm2=40C040|shorts2=40C040|socks2=40CO40 | First game = {{fbw|BFA}} 10–0 {{fbw-rt|NIG}}
([[Ouagadougou]]; September 2, 2007) | Largest win = {{fbw|BFA}} 10–0 {{fbw-rt|NIG}}
([[Ouagadougou]]; September 2, 2007) | Largest loss = {{fbw|BFA}} 0–3 {{fbw-rt|GHA}}
([[Ouagadougou]]; February 16, 2014)
{{fbw|GHA}} 3–0 {{fbw-rt|BFA}}
([[Accra]], [[Ghana]]; March 1, 2014)
{{fbw|MLI}} 5–2 {{fbw-rt|BFA}}
([[Bamako]], [[Mali]]; January 11, 2016) | World cup apps = | World cup first = | World cup best = | Olympic apps = | Olympic first = | Olympic best = | Algarve cup apps = | Algarve cup first = | Algarve cup best = | Regional name = [[African Women Cup of Nations]] | Regional cup apps = | Regional cup first = | Regional cup best = | type=women }} The '''Burkina Faso women's national football team''' is the national women's football team of Burkina Faso and is overseen by the [[Fédération Burkinabé de Foot-Ball]]. In the history of female football in the country, there have been only 5 fixtures for this team, four taking place in [[Ouagadougou]] and one in [[Accra]].[https://www.fifa.com/associations/association=bfa/fixturesresults/gender=f/index.html Burkina Faso in FIFA] ==History== Burkina Faso played their first match on 2 September 2007 in [[Ouagadougou]] against [[Niger women's national football team|Niger]] and won 10-0, the best result till today. They disputed their second match also against [[Niger women's national football team|Niger]], and again in [[Ouagadougou]], winning this time by 5-0. Their third match was again in [[Ouagadougou]], against [[Mali women's national football team|Mali]] and was the first loss, by 4-2. The Burkinabes disputed again a match on 16 February 2014, in [[Ouagadougou]], for the [[2014 African Women's Championship qualification]] against [[Ghana women's national football team|Ghana]] and lost by 3-0 in the first leg. The second leg was in [[Accra]], [[Ghana]], and lost again by 3-0, resulting in a 6-0 aggregate and lost qualification for the Championship. ==Results== ===World Cup=== {| class="wikitable" {{refimprove|date=August 2015}} {{no footnotes|date=August 2015}} {{single source|date=December 2015}} '''Haft Lang''' ({{lang-fa|هفت لنگ}}) literally meaning Seven Legs. It is the name of one of the two branches of [[Bakhtiari people]]. Haft Lang consists of four sub-branches: Dorikan, [[Dinârâni]], [[Bâbâdi]] and [[Behdârvand]]. '''Dorikan''' sub-groups are: * [[Zarrâsvand]] * Osivand * [[Mowri]] * Qand Ali * Bâbâ Ahmadi * Arab Kamari * [http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/starki-sub-tribe-of-the-haft-lang Âsteraki] '''Dinârâni''' sub-groups are: * Owrak * Lajmir Owrak * Shâloo * Nowrouzi * KoorKoor * SarGholi * Sahid * Boweiri * Âli Mahmoudi * Gorouei '''Bâbâdi''' sub-groups are: * [[Shehni]] * A'kkâshe * Râki * Galleh * Pebdeni * Nasir * Gomâr * Ârpanâhi * Ahmad Mohammadi * Âli Anvar * Molmoli '''Bahârvand''' sub-groups are: * Bakhtiârvand * Âli Jamâli * Jânaki Sardsir * Alâeddin Vand * Belivand * Âli Jamâli * Monjezi * Dinâshi * Kiârsi * Mash Mardâsi == References == *Bakhtiari History by [[Ali-Qoli Khan Bakhtiari|Sardar Assad Bakhtiari]] (Persian: تاریخ بختیاری نوشته سردار اسعد بختیاری) {{Ethnic groups in Iran}}

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Mirrorthrone | image = | caption = | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Switzerland]] | genre = [[Symphonic black metal]], {{nowrap|[[avant-garde metal]]}} | instrument = | years_active = 2000 – present | associated_acts = Unholy Matrimony, Weeping Birth | label = [[Red Stream Inc.]] | website = [http://www.mirrorthrone.com mirrorthrone.com] | Current_Members = [[Vladimir Cochet]] }}
'''Mirrorthrone''' is a [[one-man band|one-man]] [[symphonic black metal]] band formed by Vladimir Cochet in 2000.
==Biography== Mirrorthrone came into being in 2000 when it was created by Vladimir Cochet, the only member of the one man project. In late 2001 and 2002, two demo CD's were recorded, which drew the attention of Red Stream Inc. After signing to Red Stream Inc. The first Mirrothrone album was ''[[Of Wind and Weeping]]''. The follow-up album, ''[[Carriers of Dust]]'' followed in 2006, and received even more positive reviews. Following the positive feedback for his second album, Vladimir soon announced that he was preparing another album, ''[[Gangrene (album)|Gangrene]]'', which ended up being released on April 14, 2008
==Controversy== The lyrics to "A Scream to Express the Hate of a Race" were frequently misinterpreted as being racist. As a result, Cochet issued the following statement on Mirrorthrone's website:
:This is an answer to the polemic which is current at the moment on the Internet. '''No, Mirrorthrone is NOT racist, nazi, white pride or whatever you call it.''' The lyrics of the song "A Scream to Express the Hate of a Race" target the human race in its entirety. It attacks what is called the "nihilism" of a certain form of society that has been spreading around the globe and that envelops the "moral, social, religious and scientific" paradigms. I am not going to develop more for my aim is not to offer text analysis of what I have written; I only want to clarify the situation. Please read and understand at least a minimum before commenting.
==Members== * Vladimir Cochet - [[singing|vocals]], [[guitar]]s, [[bass guitar|bass]], [[synthesizer]], [[programming (music)|drum programming]]
===Past members=== * Marthe - female vocals
==Discography== * ''[[Of Wind and Weeping]]'' (Red Stream Inc., 2003) * ''[[Carriers of Dust]]'' (2006) * ''[[Gangrene (album)|Gangrene]]'' (2008) <!-- ==References== {{Reflist}}-->
==External links== *[http://www.mirrorthrone.com Official website] *[http://www.metal-archives.com/band.php?id=3485 Encyclopedia Metallum Article] *[http://antithetik.free.fr/mirrorthrone.html Review of ''Carriers of Dust'' and Interview with Vladimir'']
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Musical groups established in 2000]] [[Category:Swiss black metal musical groups]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2014}} {{Expand Serbian|date=April 2014|Манастир Свети Марко Коришки}} {{Infobox religious building |building_name=Saint Mark Koriški Monastery
Црква Светог Марка Коришког |image= |caption=Saint Mark Koriški Monastery in 1992, before destruction |location=[[Kosovo]]{{ref label|status|a|}} |geo={{Coord|42.25455|N|20.79822|E}} |religious_affiliation='''[[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian Orthodoxy]]''' |district=[[Prizren]] |status=Damaged in summer 1999 |leadership=[[Serbian Orthodox Church]] |heritage_designation = [[Protected Monuments of Culture (Serbia)|Protected Monuments of Culture]] {{SRB}} |architecture_type= |architecture_style= |facade_direction= |year_completed= around 1467 |capacity= |materials=Stone }} '''Monastery of St. Mark of Koriša''' ({{lang-sr|Манастир Свети Марко Коришки}}, {{lang-al|Manastiri i Markut të Shenjtë, Korishë}}) was a [[Serbian Orthodox]] monastery, built in 1467, located in [[Koriša]], [[Prizren]], [[Kosovo]]{{ref label|status|a|}}. The entire complex was declared a [[Protected Monuments of Culture (Serbia)|Protected Monument of Culture]] in 1959, and it is ''de jure'' protected by [[Republic of Serbia]].{{CHS-SANU|Link=318|Name=Манастир са црквно Св. Марка}} It was a single-nave church, built on a rectangular foundation. It was severely damaged after the end of the [[Kosovo War]] in 1999. == History == The ruins of the monastery of St. Mark of Koriša stands on a rocky outpost above the [[Koriša river]] near the village of [[Koriša]], near Prizren.{{cite news|title=Pomozite manastiru Svetog Marka Koriskog|publisher=KIM-info|date=August 7, 2005|url=http://www.kosovo.net/news/archive/2005/August_07/2.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501042124/http://kosovo.net/news/archive/2005/August_07/2.html|archivedate=May 1, 2011|df=}} According to preserved documents, the monastery was built by Jovan and Branko Vlahić in 1467, and it was a ''[[metochion]]'' (granted church land) to the [[Hermitage of St. Peter of Koriša]], built in the 13th century. The monastery is mentioned in the Ottoman [[defter]] of 1520. It was abandoned in the 16th century, and reactivated in the 17th century. In 1765, monk Neofit brought "many books from [[Visoki Dečani|Dečani]]". In 1779, Partenije Popović was a monk at the monastery, whither he brought several important medieval books and manuscripts.Slovo, [http://slovosrpsko.net/stari-brojevi/slovo18.pdf No. 18], p. 45 {{sr icon}} In 1859, a schoolteacher in Prizren, [[Nikola Musulin]], found [[Dušan's Code]], the constitution of the [[Serbian Empire]]. The following year the charter of the Monastery of the Holy Archangels also issued by [[Stefan Dušan]] was found in St. Nicholas Church of Koriša.{{harvnb|Radovanović|2008|p=268}} On the western side, above the rock, a [[Bell tower|belfry]] with two bells was added in 1861 as a foundation of [[Sima Andrejević]]. After that, monastery was almost abandoned up until 1995, when monastery life restarted.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} In 1999, the monastery was vandalized and set on fire,{{cite journal|author=Veselin Kesich|title=Kosovo in the History of the Serbian Church|chapter=VI|url=http://www.rastko.org.rs/kosovo/delo/11556}} when the preserved fragment of the original [[fresco]] was destroyed. The monastery had a valuable library. ==Gallery== File:Dušan's Code, Prizren manuscript, 15th c.jpg|One of the oldest manuscripts of [[Dušan's Code]], "Prizren Manuscript" was kept in Saint Mark Koriški Monastery ==See also== *[[Hermitage of St. Peter Koriški]] *[[Cultural Property of Great Importance]] *[[Tourism in Serbia]] *[[Prizren]] ==Notes and references== '''Notes:''' {| style="margin-left:13px; line-height:150%" |align="right" valign="top"|a. |{{note|status}}{{Kosovo-note}} |} '''References:''' {{reflist}} {{Serbian Orthodox Church}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saint Mark Koriski Monastery}} [[Category:Serbian Orthodox monasteries in Kosovo]] [[Category:Places of worship in Prizren]] [[Category:14th-century Serbian Orthodox church buildings]] [[Category:Destroyed churches in Kosovo]] [[Category:Cultural heritage of Kosovo]] {{Cultural-Property-stub}} {{kosovo-EO-church-stub}}

The content added does not belong in the introduction. The major tenets of the New International Economic Order are covered by its corresponding section.
revision.text:
The '''New International Economic Order''' ('''NIEO''') was a set of proposals put forward during the 1970's by some developing countries through the [[United Nations Conference on Trade and Development]] to promote their interests by improving their [[terms of trade]], increasing development assistance, developed-country tariff reductions, and other means. It was meant to be a revision of the international economic system in favour of [[Third World]] countries, replacing the [[Bretton Woods system]], which had benefited the leading states that had created it – especially the [[United States]]. This order was demanded by the [[Non-Aligned Movement]].
==History== The term was derived from the ''Declaration for the Establishment of a New International Economic Order'', adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1974, and referred to a wide range of trade, financial, commodity, and debt-related issues (1 May 1974, A/RES/S-6/3201).<ref>[http://www.un-documents.net/s6r3201.htm Declaration for the Establishment of a New International Economic Order]: United Nations General Assembly document A/RES/S-6/3201 of 1 May 1974</ref> This followed an agenda for discussions between industrial and developing countries, focusing on restructuring of the world's economy to permit greater participation by and benefits to [[developing country|developing countries]] (also known as the "North-South Dialogue"). Along with the declaration, a '''Programme of Action''' and a '''Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States''' (12 December 1974, A/RES/29/3281).<ref>[http://www.un-documents.net/a29r3281.htm Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States]: United Nations General Assembly document A/RES/29/3281 of 12 December 1974</ref> were also adopted.
In the 1970s and 1980s, the developing countries pushed for NIEO and an accompanying set of documents to be adopted by the UN General Assembly. Subsequently, however, these norms became only of [[rhetoric]]al and political value, except for some partly viable mechanisms, such as the non-legal, [[non-binding]] '''Restrictive Business Practice Code''' adopted in 1980 and the [[Common Fund for Commodities]] which came in force in 1989.
==Tenets== The main tenets of NIEO were: # Developing countries must be entitled to regulate and control the activities of [[multinational corporation]]s operating within their territory. # They must be free to [[nationalize]] or [[expropriate]] foreign property on conditions favourable to them. # They must be free to set up [[Voluntary association|associations]] of [[primary commodities]] producers similar to the [[OPEC]]; all other [[Sovereign state|States]] must recognize this right and refrain from taking economic, military, or political measures calculated to restrict it. # [[International trade]] should be based on the need to ensure stable, [[Equity (economics)|equitable]], and [[remunerative]] prices for raw materials, generalized [[Reciprocity (international relations)|non-reciprocal]] and [[non-discriminatory]] [[tariff]] preferences, as well as [[transfer of technology]] to developing countries; and should provide economic and [[technical assistance]] without any [[conditionality|strings attached]].
==Resource allocation mechanisms== Haggard and Simmons claimed that: :A number of social mechanisms are possible to affect [[resource allocation]] in any economic order. An authoritative allocation mechanism involves direct control of resources while, at the other end of the spectrum, more market-oriented private allocation mechanisms are possible. Most of the debates within the NIEO occurred over allocation mechanisms, with the southern hemisphere countries favoring authoritative solutions.
==Ideology== NIEO proposes [[central planning]], as opposed to [[free markets]].<ref>[http://www.chicagobooth.edu/faculty/selectedpapers/sp49.pdf The New International Economic Order], Harry G. Johnson, professor of economics, Woodwart Court Lecture, Oct 5, 1976, p. 6</ref> It is based on the (French) [[mercantilist]] idea that international trade would be a [[zero-sum game]] (i.e., causes no net benefits), and on the view that it does not benefit the rich at the expense of the poor. Some American economists challenge the idea of trade as a zero-sum game transaction.<ref>[http://www.chicagobooth.edu/faculty/selectedpapers/sp49.pdf The New International Economic Order], Harry G. Johnson, professor of economics, Woodwart Court Lecture, Oct 5, 1976, pp. 1-2</ref>
==Legacy== Virtually no part of the New International Economic Order was implemented. Instead, from the 1980s onward, the Bretton Woods framework would be replaced with the [[Washington Consensus]] and economic [[globalization]] on terms often described as [[neoliberal]]. The economic reach of multinational corporations, rather than being circumscribed, would be expanded significantly. Trade in commodities would shift away from state-dominated cartels towards increasingly financialized markets. The NIEO's emphasis on central planning and state-oriented resource allocation mechanisms would be almost wholly rejected, even amongst the (former) Socialist bloc, in favor of economic liberalization. The formation of the [[World Trade Organization]] and the proliferation of [[free trade agreements]] would compel the reduction of barriers to trade, generally on strictly reciprocal terms.
In Matsushita et al.'s ''World Trade Organization'', the authors explained part of the legacy of the NIEO:
:... tensions and disagreements between developed and developing countries continue: the latter expect a greater degree of special treatment than industrialized countries have afforded them. This demand was expressed comprehensively in the New International Economic Order and the Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States promoted by [[UNCTAD]] in the 1970s. Although the Charter was never accepted by developing [sic] countries and is now dead, the political, economic, and social concerns that inspired it are still present. The Charter called for restitution for the economic and social costs of colonialism, racial discrimination, and foreign domination. It would have imposed a duty on all states to adjust the prices of exports to their imports. The realization of the New International Economic Order was an impetus for developing country support for the [[Tokyo Round]] of trade negotiations. Critics of the [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] continue to state that little of substance for developing countries came out of either the Tokyo or [[Uruguay Round]]s.
The NIEO can considered to have something of a spiritual successor in the [[alter-globalization]] movement, which, like the NIEO, owes much to French academic criticism (generally rooted in [[Marxist economics]]) of international trade.
==Criticism of price regulation== The powerful countries of North America and Western Europe felt threatened by the NIEO and continuously tried to criticize and minimize it; according to economist Professor [[Harry Gordon Johnson|Harry Johnson]], the most efficient way to help the poor is to transfer resources from those most able to pay to those most in need. Instead of this, NIEO proposes that those poor countries that have monopoly power should be able to extort these transfers. In practice such power has caused most harm to other poor countries.<ref>[http://www.chicagobooth.edu/faculty/selectedpapers/sp49.pdf The New International Economic Order], Harry G. Johnson, professor of economics, Woodwart Court Lecture, Oct 5, 1976, pp. 6-7</ref>
Commanding prices above their [[market price|natural level]] usually reduces consumption and thus causes unemployment among producers. Moreover, [[price regulation]] typically gives the extra income to those in control of who is allowed to produce, e.g., to governments or land-owners.<ref>[http://www.chicagobooth.edu/faculty/selectedpapers/sp49.pdf The New International Economic Order], Harry G. Johnson, professor of economics, Woodwart Court Lecture, Oct 5, 1976, pp. 11-12</ref>
==See also== * [[Fairtrade certification]] * [[Fair trade]] * [[Liberal international economic order]] * [[New World Information and Communication Order]] * [[Trade justice]] * [[Trade Justice Movement]] * [[UNCTAD]] * [[Washington Consensus]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==Sources== * Jagdish N. Bhagwati (editor) (1977) [http://mitpress.mit.edu/catalog/item/default.asp?ttype=2&tid=7362 ''The New International Economic Order: The North-South Debate'']. {{ISBN|0-262-52042-7}}. * Cox, Robert. (1979) Ideologies and the NIEO: Reflections on some recent literature. ''International Organization'' 33 (2): 257-302. * International Progress Organization (1979) [https://www.webcitation.org/5cZaHM10G International Meeting of Experts on the New International Economic Order–Philosophical and Socio-cultural Implications] * Rothstein, Robert L. (1979) Global Bargaining: UNCTAD and the Quest for a New International Economic Order Princeton: Princeton University Press. (Traces formation of UNCTAD and its role in the NIEO.) {{ISBN|0-691-02190-2}} * Craig Murphy (1984) [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0865316643/ Emergence of the NIEO Ideology]. Boulder, Colorado: Westview. {{ISBN|0-86531-664-3}} * [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2725256 Zaidi Sattar reviews ''Threat to Development: Pitfalls of the NIEO'' by William Loehr; John P. Powelson] in ''Journal of Economic Literature'' 22(1) (March 1984) 130–131 * Breda Pavlič and Cees J. Hamelink (1985) [https://www.webcitation.org/5cZb2SoKV The New International Economic Order: Links between Economics and Communications.] UNESCO. {{ISBN|92-3-102311-X}} * Stephan Haggard and Beth A. Simmons (1987) Theories of international regimes. ''International Organization'' 41(3):498. * Robert Looney (1999) [http://web.nps.navy.mil/~relooney/routledge_15b.htm ‘New International Economic Order’] in ''Routledge Encyclopedia of International Political Economy''. {{ISBN|0-415-14532-5}} * [[Antonio Cassese]] (2001) ''International law''. Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-829998-2}}. Page 400. And, second edition, 0-19-925939-7. Page 330. * Mitsuo Matsushita, Thomas J. Schoenbaum, Petros C. Mavroidis (2003) ''The World Trade Organization: Law, Practice, and Policy''. Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-927425-8}}. Pages 388–389. * Rao, M. P. (2004) [https://www.webcitation.org/5cZZxaYpS The “New International Economic Order”] * Hugo Ruiz-Diaz (September 2005) Une tribune pour les pays du Sud. ''Le Monde diplomatique''. Pages 20 and 21. * Adam Sneyd (2005) [http://www.globalautonomy.ca/global1/glossary_entry.jsp?id=EV.0027 “New International Economic Order”] in ''Globalization and Autonomy Online Compendium'' edited by William D. Coleman and Nancy Johnson
==Further reading== * [[Gilbert Rist|Rist, Gilbert]]: ''Le développement, Histoire d'une croyance occidentale'', Presses de Sciences Po, Paris, 1996 - engl. ''The History of Development: From Western Origins to Global Faith'', 3rd edition, London: Zed Books, 2008, {{ISBN|1-84813-189-5}} Chapter 9 *The Darker Nations: A People's History of the Third World by Vijay Prashad and [[Howard Zinn]] (Editor) A "[[people's history]]" of the world's impoverished countries and their failures to oppose the United States and Soviet spheres of economic influence following World War II to the present. {{ISBN|1-56584-785-7}} * [http://legal.un.org/avl/ha/ga_3201/ga_3201.html Introductory note by Ahmed Mahiou, procedural history note and audiovisual material] on the ''Declaration on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order'' in the [http://legal.un.org/avl/historicarchives.html Historic Archives of the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law] * [http://legal.un.org/avl/ha/cerds/cerds.html Procedural history, related documents and photos] on the ''Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States'' in the [http://legal.un.org/avl/historicarchives.html Historic Archives of the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law]
==External links== *[http://www.crenieo.org/ Centre for Research on New International Economic Order (CReNIEO)]

[[1080i]] ([[16:9]]) [[High-definition television|HDTV]] (2009–present) | audio_format = [[Dolby TrueHD]] | first_run = | first_aired = December 31, 2003 | last_aired = present | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = Saturday Night Live | website = http://top-channel.tv/portokalli/ Official | production_website = http://www.top-channel.tv/ | channel = Top Channel | status = }} '''Portokalli''' (translation: Orange) is a weekly night sketch [[comedy]] and [[variety show]] filmed in [[Tirana]] in front of a live audience. The format of the show includes stand-up comedy, sketch comedy, and live music making the show similar to the "[[NBC]]" show "[[Saturday Night Live]]". Portokalli is known to make fun of everyday problems through [[humor]] and [[satire]]. It also makes fun of political figures such as [[Sali Berisha]], [[Edi Rama]], [[Hashim Thaçi]], [[Ramush Haradinaj]] and others. Portokalli reaches an audience of many ages. ==Cast== *Florian Binaj *Gazmend Paja *Erand Sojli *Ledio Lako *Salsano Rrapi *Rezart Veleshnja *Albana Perhati *Marin Orhanasi *Gent Bejko *Elvis Pupa *Romir Zalla *[[Gentian Zenelaj]] *[[Julian Deda]] *Ervina Kotolloshi *Irgen Çela *Erion Isai *Gent Hazizi *Ervin Bejleri *Xheni Hallulli *Renada Caci *Erdit Asllanaj *Suela Xhonuzi *[[Eneda Tarifa]] *Xhemi Shehu *Roland Saro *Bes Bitraku *Jorke Broka *Ilia Kaci *Kreshnik Ibrahimi *Arben Dervishi *Linda Jarani *Rudina Dembacaj *Erblin Bajko *Ergys Cekrezi *Olsi Bylyku *Aleksandër Grami *Delinda Zhupa *Genci Fuga *Gladiola Harizaj ==Viewers== Portokalli attracts over 1 million viewers in [[Albania]], [[Kosovo]]{{ref label|status|a|}}, [[Republic of Macedonia]] and Diaspora.[http://top-channel.tv/portokalli Portokalli, most watched sitcom in Albania] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{unreferenced|date=October 2008}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Portugal}} "Portugal no coração" | image = | caption = | year = 1977 | country = Portugal | artist = Paulo de Carvalho,
Fernanda Piçarra,
Luisa Basto,
Edmundo Silva,
Ana Bola,
Fernando Tordo | as = [[Os Amigos]] | with = | language = Portuguese | languages = | composer = Fernando Tordo | lyricist = [[Ary dos Santos]] | conductor = José Calvário | place = 14th | points = 18 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1977pt from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Uma flor de verde pinho | prev_link = Uma flor de verde pinho | next = Dai li dou | next_link = Dai li dou }} '''"Portugal no coração"''' ("Portugal in my heart") was the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1977]], performed in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] by [[Os Amigos]]. The song is a ballad in praise of [[Portugal]] itself. The song is about freedom, brotherhood and hope. Many of the verses of the lyrics are acclamations of the end of the ''[[Estado Novo (Portugal)|Estado Novo]]'' dictatorship that lasted for 48 years, and the end of the [[Portuguese Colonial War|wars that the Portuguese people had been forced to fight]] on the [[Portuguese Empire|African colonies]] by that regime. It's also a love hymn from Portuguese people to their ex-colonies people, whom they had fought. The song was performed eighth on the night, following [[Luxembourg]]'s [[Anne-Marie B.]] with "[[Frère Jacques (Anne-Marie Besse song)|Frère Jacques]]" and preceding the [[United Kingdom]]'s [[Lynsey de Paul]] & [[Mike Moran (music producer)|Mike Moran]] with "[[Rock Bottom (Lynsey de Paul and Mike Moran song)|Rock Bottom]]". At the close of voting, it had received 18 points, placing 14th in a field of 18. It was succeeded as [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest|Portuguese representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1978|1978 Contest]] by [[Gemini (Portuguese band)|Gemini]] with "[[Dai li dou]]". {{Eurovision Song Contest 1977}} {{Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Portugal No Coracao}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Portugal]] [[Category:Portuguese-language songs]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1977]] [[Category:1977 songs]] [[Category:Songs with lyrics by Ary dos Santos]] {{portugal-stub}}

This will update the Popes Automatically as they change --> | patriarch = | major_archbishop = | bishop = [[Antoine Vũ Huy Chương]] | bishop_title = <!-- Type of ordinary: i.e. Bishop or Archbishop. Default is Bishop --> | metro_archbishop = [[Sede Vacante]] | coadjutor = [[Dominic Nguyen Van Manh]]<ref>http://en.radiovaticana.va/news/2017/04/08/pope_francis_appoints_coadjutor_bishop_in_vietnam_%E2%80%8E/1304351</ref> | suffragans = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration); use | suffragan = for one --> | auxiliary_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> | apostolic_admin = | vicar_general = | episcopal_vicar = | archdeacons = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of first collation); use | archdeacon = for one--> | emeritus_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> <!---- Map ----> | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = <!---- Website ----> | website = [http://www.simonhoadalat.com/ Website of the Diocese] | footnotes = }} The '''Diocese of Đà Lat''' ({{lang-la|Dioecesis Dalatensis|links=no}}) is a Latin [[suffragan diocese]] of [[Roman Catholic]] church in the [[ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh City|Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh City]] in southern [[Vietnam]], yet depends on the missionary [[Roman Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples]].
Its [[cathedral]] episcopal see is Nhà Thờ Chình Toà Thánh Nicola Bari, in the southern city of [[Da Lat]], [[Lâm Đồng Province]], Central Highlands.
Its present Bishop is Antoine Vũ Huy Chương.
== Statistics and extent == As per 2014, it pastorally served 368,487 Catholics (27.8% of 1,325,000 total) on 9,764 km² in 87 parishes and 16 missions with 259 priests (143 diocesan, 116 religious), 1,413 lay religious (501 brothers, 912 sisters) and 69 seminarians. Many of its faithful belong to ethnic minorities.
== History == * The bishopric was created on November 24, 1960 as '''Diocese of Đà Lat / Ðàlạt (Tiếng Việt)''' / 大叻 (正體中文) / Dalaten(sis) (Latin), on territories split off from the then [[Apostolic Vicariate of Saigon]] and the then [[Apostolic Vicariate of Kontum]] * On 22 June 1967 it lost territory to establish the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Ban Mê Thuôt|Diocese of Ban Mê Thuôt]].
==Episcopal ordinaries== (all [[Roman Rite]])
;''Suffragan Bishops of Đà Lat * [[Simon Hoà Nguyễn Văn Hiền]] (24 November 1960 – death 5 September 1973), previously [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Sagalassus]] (1955.09.20 – 1960.11.24) as [[Apostolic Vicar]] of [[Apostolic Vicariate of Saigon|Saigon]] (Vietnam) (1955.09.20 – 1960.11.24) * Barthélémy Nguyễn Sơn Lâm, [[Sulpicians]] (P.S.S.) (30 January 1975 – 23 March 1994), next Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Thanh Hoá|Thanh Hoá]] (Vietnam) (1994.03.23 – death 2003.06.09) * [[Pierre Nguyễn Văn Nhơn]] (23 March 1994 – 22 April 2010), also President of Episcopal Conference of Vietnam (2007 – 2013); succeeded as previous [[Coadjutor Bishop]] of Đà Lat (1991.10.11 – 1994.03.23); next [[Coadjutor Archbishop]] of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hanoi|Archdiocese of Hanoi]], succeeding as Metropolitan Archbishop of Hà Nôi (2010.05.13 – ...), created [[Cardinal-Priest]] of [[S. Tommaso Apostolo]] (2015.02.14 [2015.12.06] – ...) * [[Antoine Vũ Huy Chương]] (1 March 2011 – ...); previously Bishop of [[Hưng Hóa]] (Vietnam) (2003.08.05 – 2011.03.01) ** [[Coadjutor Bishop]] (2017.04.08 – ...): [[Bishop-elect]] Dominic Nguyễn Văn Mạnh, no other prelature .

March 10, 2008 | Entrant = [[Jelena Tomašević]] | Song = [[Oro (song)|Oro]] | SF result = | Final result = 6th, 160 points }} The [[Serbia]]n National Final, [[Beovizija 2008]], was held on March 9 (semi-finals) and March 10, 2008 (finals) at [[Sava Centar]] in Belgrade to determine Serbia's representative at the [[Eurovision Song Contest]] to be held in Serbia in May. Beovizija was hosted by Kristina Radenković, Branislav Katić, Đorđe Maričić and Nina Radulović, and the winner was [[Jelena Tomašević]] with the song "[[Oro (song)|Oro]]" scoring the maximum from both the jury and televoters.{{cite web|url=http://ww1.rts.co.rs/euro/jedna_vest.asp?source=komentar&IDNews=549|title=JELENA TOMAŠEVIĆ REPRESENTS SERBIA|accessdate=2008-03-11}} 20 songs competed in the semi-finals. The top 10 songs from the semi-final qualified for the national final. {{no footnotes|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name =Special Communications Service |nativename = Спецсвязь России |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = Spetssvyaz_emb_n6024.svg |logo_width = 250px |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = {{Start date and years ago|2003|03|11}} |preceding1 = [[FAPSI]] |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Russia]] |headquarters = [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] |employees = [[Classified information in Russia|Classified]] |budget = [[Classified information in Russia|Classified]] |chief1_name = Vladimir Belanovskiy |chief1_position = Director |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = [[Federal Protective Service (Russia)|FSO]] |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = [http://www.fso.gov.ru/struktura/p2_1_1.html Official page] }}
The '''Special Communications and Information Service of the Federal Protective Service of the Russian Federation''' ('''Spetssvyaz''', ''Spetssviaz''; {{lang-ru|Служба специальной связи и информации, Спецсвязь России}}) is a [[Cryptology|cryptologic]] [[Intelligence (information gathering)|intelligence]] agency of The [[Federal Protective Service (Russia)|Federal Protective Service of Russia]] responsible for the collection and analysis of foreign communications and foreign [[signals intelligence]], as well as protecting [[Government of Russia|Russian government]] communications and [[information systems]],which involves [[information security]] and [[cryptanalysis]]/[[cryptography]]. It is the equivalent to the [[United States]] [[National Security Agency]].
==History== The Service was established in March 11, 2003 as the successor of [[FAPSI]] that was created from the 8th Main Directorate (Government Communications) and 16th Directorate (Electronic Intelligence) of the [[KGB]].
On September 25, 1991, following the [[August Coup]], Soviet president [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] dismantled the KGB into several independent departments. One of them became the Committee on Government Communications under the President of the [[Soviet Union]].
On December 24, 1991 after the disbanding of the Soviet Union the organization became the [[FAPSI|Federal Agency of Government Communications and Information under the President of the Russian Federation]].
On March 11, 2003 the agency was reorganized into the Service of Special Communications and Information (''Spetssviaz'') of the [[Federal Security Service (Russia)|Federal Security Service]] (FSB). On August 7, 2004, ''Spetssviaz'' was incorporated as a structural sub unit of the [[Federal Protective Service (Russia)|Federal Protective Service]] (FSO).
The service was created as a result of the reform March 11, 2003, on the basis of the Federal Agency for Government Communications and Information (FAPSI), initially as a special communication service of the FSO.
According to the direction then the "Regulations on the Service for Special Communications and Information under the Federal Service of the Russian Federation", the Service of Special Communication and Information (Special Communication of Russia) is a federal special communication and information, exercising their powers within the organization and provision of service, security, development and improving the governmental systems and other kinds of special links, and information gathering for federal government agencies, public authorities of the Russian Federation and state bodies.
On August 7, 2004 [[Vladimir Putin]] signed a decree "On the Federal Service of the Russian Federation". According to the decree, The Service become a part of the FSO.
==Directors of ''Spetssviaz''== From 2003 until 2010 the ''Spetssviaz'' Director was Yuri Korneev. The Director of the Special Communications Service is the Deputy Director of the [[Federal Protective Service (Russia)|Russian Federal Protective Service]]. * Yuri Kornev (2003–2010) * Alexey Mironov (2011-2017) * Vladimir Belanovskiy (Since 2017)
==See also== {{Portal|Russia|Law enforcement/Law enforcement topics}} *[[NSA]] *[[FAPSI]] *[[Federal Protective Service of Russia]] *[[Ministry of Communications and Mass Media (Russia)|Ministry of Communications and Mass Media]]
==External links== *[http://www.fso.gov.ru/struktura/p2_1_1.html Official page] in the FSO Website {{ru icon}} *[http://www.fsb.ru/fsb/npd/more.htm!id%3D10343080@fsbNpa.html The presidential decree "On creation of Special communications and information service] {{ru icon}} {{Navboxes |list = {{Law enforcement agencies of Russia}} {{Russian intelligence community}} {{Executive Authorities of Russia}} {{Signals intelligence agencies}} {{Russia topics}} }}

revision.text:
'''Umchwasho''' is a [[tradition]]al [[sexual abstinence|chastity]] [[rite]] in [[Swaziland]]. While the rite is active, unmarried women are not allowed to have sexual relations and must wear a traditional set of tassels. The tassels are usually made of [[wool]] and are worn around the neck like a [[scarf]]. Girls aged 18 and under must wear blue-and-yellow tassels and are not allowed any physical contact with males. Those aged 19 or over must wear red-and-black tassels and are allowed some physical contact with males but not [[sexual intercourse]]. Those that are caught going against umchwasho are fined one animal (typically a cow).<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/aug/30/aids.andrewmeldrum King comes courting 20,000 virgin dancers], guardian.co.uk, 2005</ref>
The most recent period of umchwasho ran between 9 September 2001 and 19 August 2005. [[Mswati III of Swaziland|King Mswati III]] imposed the ban in an effort to help stop the spread of [[HIV]] and [[AIDS]], which is particularly prevalent in the country. It was originally intended to last five years but was withdrawn one year early without any stated reason, though the ban had faced strong opposition and many women refused to wear the required woollen scarf. The King also drew criticism when he married a teen during the period, fining himself one cow for breaking the rules. When the rite ended, the tassels were burnt in a large ceremony.
